text: Now comes the moon riding over the horizon. Upon a hill a the edge of the wood squats a castle, its crude stonework bathed in cold silvery light. Queer carvings and runes decorate the ponderous gate. Heavy vines are climbing up walls. The castle is old, its unfamiliar form testament t an ancient mind and an ancient craft. Flickering candle l dances ona leaded windowpane. Inside, the corridors are dark and silent. Under low arch ceilings the uneven floors are paved with stone blocks. Perched over lintels and crouched in niches are icons wit strange animal heads.
Asleep ona straw palette in a room strewn with vegetables and crockery is Hodge, a wrinkled old retainer. A flicker candle and empty jug are beside the bed. He is snoring ge

This circular chamber at the heart of the castle is stuff with parchments, scrolls, dusty books, bronze braziers, g retorts, chemical salts, birds both stuffed and caged. An iron candelabra stands on a work table, tapers burning. I the soft glow it seems that the room is unoccupied, but n moving in the background is a shadowy figure, preparing f a magical deed. Omnia in duos: Duo in Unum: Unus in Nihil: Haec nec Quattuor nec Omnia nec Duo nec Unus nec Nihil Sunt. Nothing happens.
Come on, candles, out! But the little flames stand at attention without so much a tremble.

In Volunta Divina et Verbum Magi: Lux! Exstinguat! It's no use. There is a sigh and the figure moves forward into the light. Revealed in the glow is the discouraged f of Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice.
Carrying the candelabra, the youth trudges up a circular staircase.

The highest point of the castle is a turret, open to the stars and the night air. Here, more magic is afoot. An ol enchanter, Ulrich, Magister Ipsissimus, pours water from silver ewer into a stone bowl. As the surface ripples disappear he leans forward and gazes into the pool. All a once his face hardens as the distant sounds of screams an thunder reach his ears. Lights and shadows, reflected fro within the basin, play across his face. His frown deepens the sound of his own voice comes to him from the vision i the water вЂ” Draco draconis вЂ” suddenly squelched by th roar of flame and an ugly snarl. At that moment Galen reaches the top of the steps and hol up the candelabra.

Vide, Magister. There's something Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  wrong. Ulrich, startled from his trance, slaps the water out of basin and turns to confront his student. Galen is taken a by the old man's grim countenance.
What's the matter? What's happened?
I've just seen something. Something of consequence to you.
To me?
(calm) Yes. My own death. With a distracted gesture he causes the flames to extingu themselves.
Perhaps we had better hasten your training.
Outside the castle wall Hodge is feeding the chickens and ducks. He straightens up and squints through the early mo mists. On a distant hillock two figures are moving toward the woods.
Hobbling slowly with the aid of a pair of canes, Ulrich g his pupil across a wooden bridge and along a stream into forest.

(stern and troubled) This wood, these leaves, the birds, Script provided for educational purposes. (sharply) Have you mastered the threefold transmutation?
Of course.
(skeptical) You have?
Well, almost.
It's very difficult. Have you committed to memory undying the Codex de Profundis?
(a shrug) The first two chapters.
It's long. And what about the Ritual of Banishment as prescribed by my late master Balisarius?
To tell the truth, | haven't dared try it. What's the point, anyway?

The point? The point is you don't know it, and you're no magician without it. It was my hope to school you, to mold your faculties and wits... | still believe you have some talent. Somewhere. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

There's no time now. When I'm gone, half the powers in the universe will vanish with me. And what's the use of a few lingering skills if they're left in the hands of a child? (pause) Listen!

| don't hear anything. Ulrich gauges the young man standing before him and makes decision. Reaching under his cloak he lifts off a fine si chain with an amulet dangling from it. He drapes it aroun Galen's neck.
Here, wear this. Galen instinctively wraps his hand around the jewel. He c an ear.

Voices, singing on the road. He hastens forward to a promontory, eager to have a look. Ulrich does not follow. Instead, doffing his cloak, he wh it before him, where it magically floats a few feet off t ground. Awkwardly, the old man clambers aboard.
| don't see anything. He turns back, but the wizard is gone. A shadow falls ove him. He looks up. There, two hundred feet above the tree tops his master is soaring on the wind.

He gawks skyward. Suddenly, the old man leans down and addresses him.
(a shout) We have visitors!

Clustering together in the center of a wide reception hal is a contingent of weary peasants, awkward amidst the dus rugs, drapes and heavy furniture. Their leader is a fineb youth, not yet twenty. Like the others, he is uneasy; his name is Valerian. Hodge enters and sets a tray of mead be them. He leaves without a word. The visitors stare glumly the refreshment, but are too timorous to go near it.
Galen helps Ulrich prepare for the audience. The sorcerer peers at himself in a full4ength mirror, adjusting the he of a black robe.
Looks forbidding enough, don't you think?
Here are your sticks.

No вЂ” they'll think me infirm. You know, Balisarius wore this whenever he changed lead into gold. He could really do that, you know. | never could. Too bad вЂ” you'd stand to inherit some real wealth. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
You're in a morbid frame of mind. What's all this about dying? You don't even look sick.
(tying on a sash) You still wearing that amulet? (Galen nods) Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs to me. He backs away from the mirror and fits a silver coronet o his head.
Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a handful of that sulphurous ash over there... The sorcerer starts down a circular stone staircase.

The visitors watch warily as a door swings open and Galen makes his entrance, his face expressionless and hands pre together. He looks rather young to be the famous Ulrich. Galen allows a moment to go by, then throws his arms wide Ka-whump! and Ulrich appears in the doorway in a smoky fireball. Alarmed, the visitors retreat.
Nunc habeus lux! Pffst! around the room candles flare in their niches.
Et calor! In the fireplace, the birch logs are suddenly ablaze. Ulr totters to the hearth and extends long bony fingers towar the warmth.

| know why you're here. You're a delegation from Urland, from beyond Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts. The travelers exchange nervous glances. Valerian motions one of his companions. The man steps forward and hands ov a leather pouch. One by one, Valerian places the contents the table for Ulrich's inspection.
A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened. (pause) Scales. At this, Ulrich advances and closely examines three shimm irridescent disks as big as saucers.
All right. How did you come by these?
(proudly) | found them. At the mouth of the lair.
(grim) What else? Valerian reaches under his jerkin and withdraws what appe to be a curved sword. He jabs it into the table. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
A claw.
That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the gods! He runs a finger along a serrated edge and gazes bleakly his visitors.
And you want me to do battle with that? Valerian has lost all trace of timidity.

Who else can we turn to? We all know what we're dealing with here. This is a basilicok. (he takes a step forward) A cockatrice. (another step, bolder) A dragon. (he leans close to Ulrich) This is no stag, no bear, no natural creature. This is one of your kind. And only a necromancer such as yourself can rid us of it.
Did you try the Meredydd sisters? What about Rinbod? I've heard it said he killed a dragon once.
They're all dead. You're the only one left. With a sigh, Ulrich lowers himself into a chair. He rubs withered legs and shakes his head. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
It's a long way to Urland.
Every quarter, upon the solstices and the equinoxes there's a new victim. Greil, a grizzled peasant, speaks up.
My daughter, for one.
My sister... cousins...
All women?
Girls. Virgins, to be exact, chosen by lot. Galen edges over to the table and inspects the scales and tooth.
Master, don't you think вЂ”
Silence! He broods for a long time.
Are you afraid of dragons?

No. Sorcerers and dragons go backa long long time together. If it weren't for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any dragons. (pause) All right. I'll go. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

| know of this dragon. Vermithrax Pejorative: she's four hundred years old. As far as | can tell she's the last of her kind. Very appropriate that I'm the one to finish her off, don't you think? (he tries out the crutches) There. Flatten the highest mountain. What say you, Galen? (no answer) Speak up. (still no answer) You, Hodge. Hodge mutters something inaudible and grimly keeps packin
(to Galen) While I'm gone see you keep your nose in your books and your hands out of my reagents. Leave my instruments alone too. Galen crouches against the castle wall; he regards his ma sullenly.

I'm not worried about the road.

Don't mock me. Galen gets up and calls out to the Urlanders.
You pilgrims: You're used to lotteries. Why not draw straws to see who'll be first to carry ironshanks here. This is too much for Hodge.
Hold your tongue. If the master's got a mind to go, he'll go. Galen approaches the old sorcerer.
Send me. You're always saying | need seasoning. | need a test. Let me go.
You're not ready.
I'm ready for anything.
(wan smile) Don't be so hasty. Your time will come. The walkers are ready to set forth. Hodge picks up his pa steps forward and pulls open the great gate.

Three mounted men are outside the gate, helmets on their heads, swords on the belts and longbows across their shoulders. They look formidable. The Urlanders take a ste Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  backward.
Tyrian!? Tyrian is a lean, heavily bearded nobleman. There is a co of arms on the shield strapped to the pommel of his saddl
(amiable) Good morning, all.
We're not afraid of you. Give us the road.

Why, the road is yours. All the way to Urland. It's a long journey, isn't it? But when you're in search of a sorcerer, | suppose no distance is too great. Sensing trouble, Galen moves forward. Ulrich touches his arm.
(under his breath) Say nothing. Galen hears the urgency in the old man's voice and obeys. Hodge takes it upon himself to deal with the strangers.
What do you want with us?
Well, like my good friends here, I've come for a bit of black magic. No doubt you've heard of our troubles at home. This is Cragganmore, is it not?
Aye, this be the place of Ulrich. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Tyrian dismounts and saunters up to the old magician.
And here we have the mystical presence himself, no?
You'd best keep your distance вЂ” and your manners.

If he's ready to lay a dragon in its grave, he's got nothing to fear from me. (turns to the Urlanders) I've no more love for that creature than you lot. Nor has the King. But, before you stir things up, don't you think ita good idea to see you've got the right man for the job?
Aha - it's a test you're looking for. We don't do tests.

I'm sure you don't. They never do tests - and not many real deeds either. Oh, conversation with your grandmother's shade in a darkened room, the odd love potion or two... but comes a doubter, well then, it's the wrong day, the planets are not aligned, the entrails aren't favorable, we don't do tests.
We've got no doubts. We require no test.
And you're not going to get one. When Ulrich finally speaks, his voice is low and Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  authoritative.
(to Galen) Go to the conjuring room. The iron box. Fetch me the dagger within. Galen's eyes widen with alarm.
The dagger. Be quick. Galen dashes into the castle. Ulrich gazes almost shyly a Tyrian.
You shall have your test.

Galen comes puffing up the steps, locates the iron box, a flings it open. Amidst the tawdry paraphernalia of a professional magician is an ivory-handled dagger covered with runic inscriptions. Galen eagerly examines it to see how the blade might twist aside or collapse into the hand but it is all too genuine. A murder weapon.
(impatient) Where are you, boy? I'm waiting. Galen throws open a window and looks down into the courty He displays the dagger.
Not this one, was it?

The very one. Let it fall. Galen hesitates, then tosses it. Tumbling end over end, i arcs downward. The old conjurer calmly stretches out a ha and plucks it neatly out of the air. Quick, back to the window and climb down the vine... Smack! the heavy shutters seal him in.
Ulrich takes Tyrian's arm and guides the point of the dag to his breastbone.

Vita regula, vita hieratica! Everyone is filled with dread. Hodge is shaking. From the castle come the rattling of shutters and Galen's muffled cries. A sick sarcastic smile has crept over Tyrian's lip He tenses himself to thrust.
Go on. Don't worry, you can't hurt me.

Galen stops hammering and presses his face to a crack in shutter. Below he can see the participants in this grisly drama. He holds his breath. Tyrian makes a sudden movemen and buries the blade in Ulrich's chest. But the sorcerer stands unbent, seemingly unhurt. Then, after a long momen he slowly sags forward over the dagger and the hand that holds it. Tyrian shrinks back and allows the body to fall a heap. Very quickly he remounts. In another moment he an his companions are gone. The others are riveted in horror Hodge sinks to his knees and wails his grief. Galen turns away from the window and gazes blankly into t gloomy conjuring room. Click! The doors unlatch themselve and swing open.

While the visitors wordlessly look Galen touches a burning brand to the kindling. At first t fire catches normally enough, but when the flames start t envelop the body they suddenly turn pale green, producing unearthly roar. The onlookers back away from the intense heat.
The erstwhile apprentice stands his ground, blinking back tears, his face weirdly illuminated by the fire.

At the window he looks down to see Hodge bi farewell to the delegation from Urland. Valerian is the l to leave. He pauses at the gate and glances up at Galen. Then he moves on. Hodge вЂ” what are you doing? Hodge quickly conceals the pouch.

Galen and Hodge labor to the crest of a grassy hill and t to look back across a wide valley. There on another hillt on the far side sits Cragganmore, lit by the red rays of setting sun. Galen removes the amulet from his neck and clutches it in his fist. Hodge is bug-eyed to see it.
Be careful with that! You don't know what you're doing.
Stand back! He raises his hands toward the castle and calls out:
Cragganmore! Domus noni am! Silva celet!

The vines on the castle walls begin to twitch and stretch magically brought to animate life. They flow upward over masonry, branching out and covering every surface, then u onto the roof. Galen and Hodge trudge along an overgrown cart-track unde an arch of trees.
Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we dwell. It doesn't matter who you are, a king in his robes, a peasant in his rags, when your time comes, no magic can save you...
I guess... The apprentice's mind is elsewhere: he's got a coin hover in mid-air above his palm, bobbing gently as he walks.

..the kindest lord a man could ask for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was fussy about his bath. And you'd think he could boil his own eggs with the snap of a finger, but no, he had old Hodge do it, of course. (snurfling) Up before five | was, mucking out the cages, slopping the pigs, and never once got so much as a thankyou or a pat on the back... (through tears) I'm going to miss him.
Me too... He plucks a low-hanging leaf, waves a hand over it, and watches it turn into a spray of daffodils.

No you don't. All you care about is the tricks and knavery. Well, you Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  don't pull any wool over these old eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk before you fill his shoes, you mark my word.
What's the matter, Hodge, pack too heavy? Here. He gives the pack a slap. It flies out of its harness and floats alongside them. Hodge snatches it back and clutche it tightly.
Careful with that!
Too cold, is it? A great coat drapes itself over Hodge's shoulders.
Stop it!
Too warm? The greatcoat disappears, as do the rest of his garments, leaving him in his smalls.
(spluttering) Stop it, |say! Out of respect for the master! Suppressing a grin, Galen mercifully waves his hand and restores Hodge to his usual costume.
I've got as much respect for the master as anyone, old man. But вЂ” then again, I'm master now.

I left my farm with seeds unplanted, calves unborn, nothing but a wife to chase down the strays, and for what? A funeral, that's what. He walks up and down behind Valerian.
Because some people said, find a magician. Not just a local fellow, an import, a good forty leagues from home. An all-powerful necromancer. Ha вЂ”some necromancer! Malkin, an older man, speaks up.
Hold your tongue, Greil. Sit. Eat.
I'll not sit. I'll not eat. See you the Great Bear. His tail points east. It's the equinox. Have you forgotten? Or rather not think about it?

(miserable) He's right. | brought us here for nothing. May the gods help whoever's daughter it is tonight. There is a noise from the darkness beyond the campfire. (growl) Well, you've found us.

A few words, that's all. You were looking for a conjurer.
He's dead.

How say you? Galen surveys the puzzled faces. He draws himself up and plunges in:

My lord Ulrich is no longer. All that you asked of him, you may now expect of me. The dangers he would face, | will now conquer. The task he would undertake | will now fulfill. lam Galen Bradwardyn, inheritor of Ulrich's craft and knowledge, and | am the Sorcerer you seek. Script provided for educational purposes. What's come over you, anyway? Have you lost your wits? He propels Galen out of harm's way and sits him down on t other side of the fire. Greil nurses his jaw.

It's not just him. It's all of us. It's the equinox. They both look up at the moon.

The moon shines down on the far reaches of the Kingdom of Urland, coldly lighting a barren landscape filled with th skeletons of dead trees, blackened rock and bare ground.
